ygData.subject: Re: There's More To Him Then Meets The Eye.
ygData.msgSnippet: Tavatron had relaxed considerably, and had decided that a sitting position would be more comfortable. The flight wasn’t as bad as she had previously thought,

Tavatron had relaxed considerably, and had decided that a sitting position 
would be more comfortable. The flight wasn�t as bad as she had previously 
thought, and despite her rather negative attitude towards anything that 
involved her feet leaving the ground, she was actually enjoying herself. The 
sky was painted a deep, rich black amidst a nest of stars and various 
creatures of the night. She breathed deeply, something she tended to do when 
she was in pleasant surroundings. She had come a long way since she first 
joined the forces.

Despite her many failings she had triumphed in the face of adversity more 
times than she could remember. Her past was a blur of weapons fire and 
battle, marked with the occasional �bot who had made such an impact on her 
life that she cared to remember them at all. She always had trouble 
remembering things, but them, those �bots, she would never forget. The more 
she thought about it the more she realized just how much Dinobot meant to 
her. He was a friend, a battling companion that could best her in almost any 
match. Only a few had been better than her, and Dinobot was one of them. Her 
ears swiveled back in order to hear his reply. So, she did make a 
difference. That was all she needed to hear.

Perhaps there was a bit of emotion in his voice, but that could just be 
wishful thinking. However, perhaps she had finally been able to crack his 
rough exterior, but who was she kidding? He�d never see her as more than a 
friend, no matter how she saw him. She had to admit, he wasn�t that bad as 
�bots went. He was definitely loyal, not to mention caring, in his own 
special way that is:

"I suppose we all make a difference."

She knew he had made a difference in her life, but whether it would be more 
than that was up to him. She wasn�t going to push him into anything. She was 
content with being able to talk to him without ending up in a screaming 
match. Tavatron shifted herself so that her right leg was bent and her left 
one was hanging over the edge of Necromancer�s back. She leaned back until 
she was laying with her wolven head resting on her arms.

She looked up at the sky, searching the stars for any familiar sparks. She 
had lost so many friends� but she would never forget them. That much she was 
sure of. With a final sigh she continued to search the heavens, wondering 
what would become of her, of all the warriors, once there were no more 
battles to be fought and no more wars to be won. When the time came she 
would know, until then she would be content to lay here and gaze skyward:

"It�s a beautiful night."
